adjective.description: Quick to detect or respond to slight changes, signals, or influences.
examples: the new method of protein detection was more sensitive than earlier ones
spiders are sensitive to vibrations on their web

adjective.description: (of a person or a person's behavior) having or displaying a quick and delicate appreciation of others' feelings.
examples: I pay tribute to the Minister for his sensitive handling of the bill

adjective.description: Kept secret or with restrictions on disclosure to avoid endangering security.
examples: he was suspected of passing sensitive information to other countries

noun.description: A person who is believed to respond to occult influences.

origin: Late Middle English (in the sense sensory): from Old French sensitif, -ive or medieval Latin sensitivus, formed irregularly from Latin sentire feel. The current senses date from the early 19th century.
